definition: pavilion in the air (idiom); unrealistic Utopian construction/castles in Spain/imaginary future plans
to hit (the mark)/to be hit by/to suffer/to win (a prize, a lottery)
house with more than 1 story/storied building/floor/CL:層|层[ceng2],座[zuo4],棟|栋[dong4]

sentences.english: Your plan is merely a castle in the air.
sentences.chinese: 你的计划仅是空中楼阁而已。

sentences.english: My Shanghai mansion may prove to be a castle in Spain after all.
sentences.chinese: 我在上海买栋大厦的梦想只不过是座空中楼阁而已。

sentences.english: Their calculations have all been proved to be castles in the air.
sentences.chinese: 他们的打算证明，全都不过是空中楼阁。

sentences.english: You are building a castle in the air .
You must study harder and harder, otherwise entering college may prove to be a castle in the air.
sentences.chinese: 你学习必须努力，否则上大学可能是空中楼阁罢了。

sentences.english: Their plan is merely a castle in the air because it is simply impracticable.
sentences.chinese: 他们的计划不过是空中楼阁而已，因为它根本行不通。

sentences.english: Your scheme is merely a castle in the air.
sentences.chinese: 你的计划只不过是空中楼阁。

sentences.english: Fame is emptiness, because there have been greater men than he.
sentences.chinese: 名望是空中楼阁，因为还有比他更伟大的人。

sentences.english: Don't trust him any more , he is always living in a castle in Spain as a daydreamer .
sentences.chinese: 别再相信他了，他是个一直住在空中楼阁里的空想家。

definition: unreal/illusory/imaginary/vague and with nothing in it
towering buildings are built up from the ground (idiom)/great oaks from little acorns grow
pinyin: wan4 zhang4 gao1 lou2 ping2 di4 qi3

definition: lit. military tactics on paper (idiom)/fig. theoretical discussion that is worse than useless in practice/armchair strategist/idle theorizing/cf Zhao Kuo 趙括|赵括 leading an army of 400,000 to total annihilation at battle of Changping 長平之戰|长平之战 in 260 BC
unattainable/far-fetched/out of reach/exceedingly remote or distant
lit. to allay one's hunger using a picture of a cake/to feed on illusions (idiom)
see 黃粱夢|黄粱梦[huang2 liang2 meng4]
lit. to pile up (bricks)/to pack/fig. to pad out (writing with fancy phrases)/ornate rhetoric
to have one's feet firmly planted on the ground (idiom); realistic without flights of fancy/steady and serious character
